Award.AwardTitle: The Computer Science Academic, Retention, and Enrichment Program (CARE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Computer Science Academic, Retention, and Enrichment (CARE) program at Kutztown University will address a common challenge in computer science programs, namely creating a student body that is representative of the general population. The CARE program will recruit highly capable academically talented students who have financial need, and will provide academic support and resources to retain and graduate these students. Extra-curricular activities will encourage skill development that will prepare students for their profession, and will create a culture that is more welcoming to a diverse community of students. The project will generate evidence regarding what actually attracts and retains students in computer science, which can then be used by other programs to address the challenge of attracting and retaining woman and underrepresented groups to computer science.

The CARE will provide an opportunity to study how to recruit more academically talented students, including underrepresented students, into computer science, how to help them persist, and how to graduate them as competent and confident professionals. The primary focus will be on retention and graduation, which will be supported by building a sense of community among scholarship recipients. The program will be structured to include "High Impact Educational Activities," expanding existing student supports, such as the Computer Science learning community, and building upon outreach activities for high school students. Students will receive advising, mentoring, tutoring, supplemental instruction, internship and externship opportunities, and research opportunities. The lessons learned from the curricular and co-curricular activities will be of value to other STEM disciplines, especially those with little diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computer Science Academic, Retention, and Enrichment Program (CARE)  program at Kutztown University was designed to attract academically talented students with financial need who have an interest in computer science and information technology (CSIT).  As part of the program, CARE also targeted underrepresented groups. This was the first coordinated effort on the part of the Computer Science Department at Kutztown University to actively address the issue of the underrepresentation of minorities and women in the program. We followed the approach and successes of other institutions that have dealt with the same problem to obtain desired results. A clear leader in this effort, based on their success with recruiting women into their computer science program, is Carnegie Mellon University. Since 1995 they have been pursuing the goal of making the Computer Science program at Carnegie Mellon an institution that is as friendly to women as it is to men. The grant funded 31 scholars, 19 of whom completed degrees in computer science or information technology, with 1 additional graduate in another STEM field, biology, a 65% completion rate. In addition to scholarships, the grant provided funds for supplemental instructors and tutors, student mentors for scholars, graduate assistants for data collection, and two faculty for administration and assessment of the program.

 With 19/31 = 61% of recruited scholars being female, with a retention rate of 13/19 = 68% of female scholars (13/31 = 42% overall), our results exceed both the Department of Computer Science and Information Technology?s overall population of approximately 13% female undergraduate students, and national representation ranging from 13% to 20% in recent national surveys.

Recruitment of Hispanic students was insufficient, based on the number of Hispanic students in the department, because qualified students did not apply. Hispanic students needed proactive encouragement to apply. Retention of African-American students needs improvement.

Successful-scholar academic years in the program / all-scholar academic years in the program gives the value 55 years / 71 years = 77%. Successful-scholar funds awarded / all-scholar funds awarded gives the value $402,823.50 / $523,760.50 = 77% of funds spent on successful STEM scholars. In terms of scholar years and funds spent on scholarships, 77% approaches the 80% goal of Assessment Objective 1.

Assessment of scholar activities found that student success in the program could be predicted with 71% accuracy simply by determining whether a student made at least one entry in an on-line journal (blog) in which scholars were instructed to write at the beginning of each semester, without faculty enforcing that request. Discounting a non-blogging scholar who had to leave the university for medical reasons raises that accuracy to 76%. This finding is important because the measure is objective and occurs early in the academic career, making it useful for identifying at-risk students. In addition, incoming students with 6 or more credits accumulated via prior course work or equivalency exam results had a higher retention rate than students with fewer than 6, making incoming credits another early indicator for at-risk scholars needing extra support.

Student activities included social gatherings with peers, faculty members, and industrial mentors, conference travel, a learning community, ungraded class some semesters, and interaction with student supplemental instructors and tutors. All scholars were provided an academic advisor that was part of the grant program, with all female scholars assigned a female or a female-friendly advisor.
